Tom, excellent stuff. Thanks very much for that. I had another 
translation=
 as well form a friend in Japan. He wrote pretty much as you 
did. ( see li=
nk )

http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/nmb/forum/index.php?action=3Ddispl=
ay&forumid=3D1&msgid=3D2644

I have Suishinshi Masahide no sono Ichimon and=
 looked through again and 
sure enough, there you are. There just seems to =
be a couple of lines 
there about the tsuba, unless buried in the paragraph=
s that follow. They 
are certainly excellent looking tsuba and I may have t=
o try and track 
one down when I get to Japan, just for a look at least.

C=
heers and thanks again.

Cheers

Richard






>
>
> Richard-
> 	In the boo=
k Suishinshi Masahide to sono ichimon, there is an  
> oshigata of a simila=
r tsuba and a few lines, explaining that he  
> indeed did make more but no=
t many. If I understood correctly all iron  
> tosho style tsuba appropriat=
ely enough. I would love to see one in  
> person myself.
> 		Your page say=
s; This is a Tosho tsuba with kokuin impressed in a  
> tsuchime-ji by Suis=
hinshi Masahide. Masahides' great contribution to  
> the world of the Japa=
nese sword is evidenced by one well known fact,  
> and that is that the Sh=
inshinto era begins with the emergence of this  
> very artist. His strengt=
h, his energy are evidenced by his having  
> answered the demands of the t=
imes all the while fostering over 100  
> students. He was an extraordinary=
 educator.
> 	In Token Benkyo Kai first place is Ten (Heaven), second place=
 is Chi  
> (Earth) and third place is "Jin" (Man). With this work Masahide=
 makes  
> reference to that as well as Buddhistic themes. It is thought wi=
th  
> this tsuba Masahide is showing us a miniature universe, his kokuin  =

> reading "Niten" is an abbreviation of Nitenji, a guardian deity who  
> =
is the same as Nichirin (the orb of heaven, the sun).
> 	In Bunsei Gannen M=
asahide changed his name to Amahide, one story has  
> it that the "Ama" wa=
s granted to him by lord Akimoto, suggesting a  
> link to the first great =
swordsmith Amakuni and "lord of swordmakers  
> heaven."
> 	The metal is a =
bit on the hard side but the color and texture are  
> excellent, this is a=
 rare and well known piece.
>
> 	At least that is what I think it says...
